detect and set the processor to use

if torch.cuda.is_available():

        print("Machine type:", platform.machine())

    else:

else:

Using GPU: NVIDIA RTX A3000 12GB Laptop GPU




load the model
This model is obtained from the Meta.

#what sam model to use (see their github for diff options, but b is the smallest one = less crashing)
sam_checkpoint = "sam_vit_b_01ec64.pth"
model_type = "vit_b"

#added print statements to check due to previous crashing issues
try: 
    sam = sam_model_registry[model_type](checkpoint=sam_checkpoint)

except Exception as e:
    print("NOPE not loaded")

YUP all loaded




Set up to run the SAM model

sam.to(device=device)

#Below are parameters that seem to be good for chaing min size allowed, how detailed the model looks for masks, etc 


#There are several tunable parameters in automatic mask generation that control 
# how densely points are sampled and what the thresholds are for removing low 
# quality or duplicate masks. Additionally, generation can be automatically 
# run on crops of the image to get improved performance on smaller objects, 
# and post-processing can remove stray pixels and holes. 
# Here is an example configuration that samples more masks:
#https://github.com/facebookresearch/segment-anything/blob/9e1eb9fdbc4bca4cd0d948b8ae7fe505d9f4ebc7/segment_anything/automatic_mask_generator.py#L35    

#Rerun the following with a few settings, ex. 0.86 & 0.9 for iou_thresh
# and 0.92 and 0.96 for score_thresh

mask_generator_ = SamAutomaticMaskGenerator(
     model=sam,
    points_per_side=32,
    pred_iou_thresh=0.9,
    stability_score_thresh=0.96,
    crop_n_layers=1,
    crop_n_points_downscale_factor=2,
    min_mask_region_area=100,    # Requires open-cv to run post-processing
)

Apply the defined mask generator to process the image.
This a very expensive (time consuming) process.

start = time.perf_counter()

masks = mask_generator_.generate(image)

end = time.perf_counter()
elapsed = end - start

print("The number of masks:", len(masks))
print(f"Mask generation took {elapsed:.2f} seconds")

        for i in range(3):
            img[:,:,i] = color_mask[i]
        ax.imshow(np.dstack((img, m*0.35)))

title: Image Gallery and Upload Guide
text: This guide explains how to use the forensic cell image gallery and upload functionality in the SSG High School Forensics Application. The system allows users to view sample images, upload their own cell images, and process them using AI-powered analysis tools.

title: Image Gallery and Upload Guide
text: This guide explains how to use the forensic cell image gallery and upload functionality in the SSG High School Forensics Application. The system allows users to view sample images, upload their own cell images, and process them using AI-powered analysis tools.

title: Image Gallery and Upload Guide
text:
Image Gallery
The image gallery is organized into three main sections, each serving a specific purpose in the forensic analysis workflow.

Sample Images
The Sample Images section contains pre-loaded reference images of different cell types:

Buccal Cells: Epithelial cells collected from the inside of the cheek, commonly used in forensic DNA analysis
Epidermal Cells: Skin cells that can be found in fingerprints and touch DNA samples
Saliva Cells: A mixture of epithelial cells found in biological evidence

These images are provided for educational purposes and can be used to:

Learn to identify different cell types
Practice with the image processing tools
Compare against uploaded images


Using Sample Images

Navigate to the gallery page
Browse images organized by cell type
Hover over any image to reveal action buttons:

View: Opens the full-size image in a new tab
Process: Sends the image to the AI analysis pipeline





Uploaded Images
This section displays all images that have been uploaded by users through the upload tool.

How to Upload Images

Navigate to the Upload page
Click the upload area or drag and drop an image file
Supported formats: JPG, JPEG, PNG
Once uploaded, the image will appear in the Uploaded Images section of the gallery



Processing Uploaded Images
After uploading an image:

Go to the gallery page
Find your image in the Uploaded Images section
Hover over the image to reveal action buttons
Click Process to analyze the image
Wait for the processing to complete (indicated by status messages)
View the processed result in the Processed Images section




Processed Images
This section contains all images that have been analyzed by the AI segmentation and identification tools.
Processed images include:

Segmented cell boundaries
Cell type identification
Analysis metadata


Viewing Processed Results

Click on any processed image to view it full-size
Processed images are named with a processed_ prefix
Results are stored persistently and can be reviewed at any time

title: Image Gallery and Upload Guide
text:
Technical Implementation






Note



This section contains technical details about the system architecture and implementation. Feel free to skip this if you’re primarily interested in using the application.



Architecture
The gallery system uses a dynamic, API-driven architecture:
Frontend (Quarto/HTML/JS) → NGINX → FastAPI Backend → File System


API Endpoints
The backend provides three main endpoints for the gallery:

GET /api/gallery/sample-images: Returns organized list of sample images by cell type
GET /api/gallery/uploaded-images: Returns list of user-uploaded images
GET /api/gallery/processed-images: Returns list of processed images



Image Storage
Images are organized in the following directory structure:
images/
├── sample-gallery-images/
│   ├── buccal_cells/
│   ├── epidermal_cells/
│   └── saliva_cells/
├── uploaded-images/
└── processed-images/


Processing Workflow

User selects an image to process
Frontend fetches the image as a blob
Image is sent to /api/process-img endpoint via POST request
Backend processes the image using the SAM2 model (or current processing logic)
Processed image is saved to processed-images/ directory
Frontend refreshes the Processed Images gallery
User is notified of successful processing

title: Image Gallery and Upload Guide
text:
Best Practices

For Students

Start by exploring sample images to learn different cell types
Upload clear, well-focused microscope images for best results
Process images one at a time to avoid overwhelming the system
Compare processed results against sample images to verify accuracy



For Educators

Use sample images for demonstrations and teaching
Guide students to upload their own collected samples
Review processed images with students to discuss cell identification
Leverage the gallery for comparative analysis exercises

Who This Page Is For
This section of the documentation is intended for developers or those who are hoping to look under the hood of this project. If you know little about coding or are trying to figure out how to add your own lessons to the application, then this section of documentation is NOT for you. If you are looking for documentation about how to make your own lesson, please see the Creating New Lessons guide.

title: Developer Documentation
text:
Location of Files
These file locations will be relative to the root directory (ssg-hs-forensics-app/).
forensics-ui/ - contains the files used to generate the graphics (the actual website itself). Within this directory: * _site/ - contains the rendered pages of the website. * .quarto - contains the intermediate files generated by Quarto before the files in ’_site/’ are created. (DOUBLE CHECK THAT THIS IS CORRECT) * cell-gallery/ - contains the Quarto/QMD and CSS files needed to generate the interactive cell gallery; whenever the ‘process’ button is pressed, it sends the specific image to the backend for processing and retrieves the processed image. * lesson-1/ - contains the QMD and CSS files needed to generate the lesson pages of the first lesson. * upload/ - contains the QMD and CSS files responsible for upload functionality; sends uploaded images to the backend for processing and retrieves the results. * _quarto.yml - file responsible for coordinating the other files for the front-end, and provides the website bar necessary to navigate the different pages of the website.
forensics-backend/ - contains the files that manage the whole system and process uploaded images. Within this directory: * app/ - contains the following files: - Dockerfile - manages setting up the Docker compartments and running the server. - main.py - contains the server functions, which allow images to be processed and retrieved. - requirements.txt - contains the names of Python libraries required for this project; ‘Dockerfile’ uses this file to know what libraries to install when setting up the Docker compartments and webserver. - run_sam2.py - responsible for processing uploaded images; used by ‘main.py’. * nginx/ - contains the following file: - default.conf - configurations for the Docker compartments; manages pathways between systems, including connecting containers to the outside world and rerouting calls to their intended compartments. * docker-compose.yml - responsible for Docker container creation, and leaves ‘windows’ open so files outside certain compartments can be used.
images/ - contains the images used in the website. Within this directory: * processed-images/ - contains the processed images (images that have been run through the SAM model). * sample-gallery-images/ - contains the sample images that are pre-loaded into the gallery. * uploaded-images/ - contains the images users have uploaded.
reports/ - contains the QMD files that render into the documentation for this project. Within this directory: (TODO: ADD TO) * development.qmd - the file that renders this very file; documentation indended for developers or those who are interested in the behind-the-scenes information.

title: Developer Documentation
text:
Overview of Coding Languages Used
This project primarily uses Python, JavaScript, CSS, and HTML (through Quarto). The actual processing of files relies on Python code. JavaScript is used within the QMD (Quarto) files in order to add interactivity to the generated HTML pages, including APIs that allow images to be sent to the backend server for processing and to request images from the server. Quarto is used to generate the HTML files that make up the website.

title: Creating New Lessons
text:
Overview
This guide explains how to create new forensic science lessons for the SSG High School Forensics Application. Lessons are built using Quarto (QMD files) and can include text, images, videos, interactive quizzes, and custom styling.

title: Creating New Lessons
text:
Lesson Structure

Directory Organization
Each lesson is contained in its own directory within forensics-ui/. The structure follows this pattern:
forensics-ui/
├── lesson-1/           # Example lesson
│   ├── index.qmd       # Lesson landing page
│   ├── 1-objectives.qmd
│   ├── 2-saliva.qmd
│   ├── 3-skin.qmd
│   ├── 4-blood.qmd
│   ├── 5-buccal.qmd
│   ├── 6-epithelial.qmd
│   ├── 7-quiz.qmd
│   ├── 8-analysis-introduction.qmd
│   ├── styles.css      # Lesson-specific styles
│   └── assets/         # Images, videos, etc.
└── lesson-2/           # Your new lesson
    ├── index.qmd
    ├── 1-topic.qmd
    ├── 2-topic.qmd
    └── ...

title: Creating New Lessons
text:
Creating a New Lesson

Step 1: Create Lesson Directory

Navigate to forensics-ui/
Create a new directory with a descriptive name (e.g., lesson-2, dna-analysis, etc.)

cd forensics-ui
mkdir lesson-2
cd lesson-2


Step 2: Create the Index Page
Create an index.qmd file as the lesson landing page:
---
title: "Lesson 2: DNA Analysis"
---

## Introduction

Brief overview of what this lesson covers.

## Topics Covered

- [Topic 1](1-topic1.qmd)
- [Topic 2](2-topic2.qmd)
- [Quiz](3-quiz.qmd)


Step 3: Create Lesson Pages
Each lesson page should be a separate QMD file. Number them sequentially for organization.
Example: 1-introduction.qmd
---
title: "Introduction to DNA"
---

## What is DNA?

Your content here...

### Key Concepts

- Concept 1
- Concept 2

## Next Steps

[Continue to next section →](2-structure.qmd)


Step 4: Add Custom Styling (Optional)
Create a styles.css file for lesson-specific styling:
/* Lesson 2 Custom Styles */
.lesson-header {
  background-color: #4a90e2;
  padding: 2rem;
  color: white;
}

.key-term {
  font-weight: bold;
  color: #2c3e50;
}
Reference it in your QMD files:
---
title: "Page Title"
format:
  html:
    css: styles.css
---


Step 5: Add to Site Navigation
Edit forensics-ui/_quarto.yml to add your lesson to the site navigation:
website:
  navbar:
    left:
      - text: Home
        href: index.qmd
      - text: Lesson 1
        href: lesson-1/index.qmd
      - text: Lesson 2        # Add this
        href: lesson-2/index.qmd
      - text: Gallery
        href: cell-gallery/gallery.qmd


Step 6: Render and Test
cd forensics-ui
quarto render
Open the generated site in _site/ to test your lesson.

title: Creating New Lessons
Creating New Lessons
text:
Best Practices

Content Organization

Break content into manageable chunks: Each page should cover one main topic
Use descriptive filenames: 3-dna-extraction.qmd is better than page3.qmd
Number pages sequentially: Makes navigation and ordering clear
Include navigation links: Add “Previous” and “Next” links at the bottom of each page



Styling

Keep styles consistent: Use existing lesson styles as a template
Use semantic HTML: Use <article>, <section>, etc. appropriately
Make it responsive: Test on different screen sizes
Follow accessibility guidelines: Use alt text, proper heading hierarchy, etc.



Media Files

Optimize images: Compress images before adding them
Use web-friendly formats: JPG for photos, PNG for graphics, WebP when possible
Provide alt text: Always include descriptive alt text for images
Host large videos externally: Use YouTube or Vimeo for large video files



Navigation

Provide clear navigation: Table of contents, breadcrumbs, next/previous links
Link back to lesson index: Always provide a way to return to the lesson overview
Use descriptive link text: “Learn about DNA structure” instead of “Click here”

## Introduction

DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid) is the hereditary material in humans and most other organisms.

:::{.callout-note}
DNA is found in nearly every cell of the human body!
:::

## The Double Helix

![DNA Double Helix](assets/dna-helix.png){width=50%}

The structure of DNA was discovered by Watson and Crick in 1953.

### Key Components

1. **Sugar-phosphate backbone**
2. **Nitrogenous bases**
   - Adenine (A)
   - Thymine (T)
   - Guanine (G)
   - Cytosine (C)

## Interactive Activity

Try identifying the bases in this DNA sequence:

<div class="activity">
  <p>Sequence: ATCG TACG GCTA</p>
  <input type="text" placeholder="Your answer">
  <button>Check Answer</button>
</div>

## Quiz Yourself

:::{.callout-tip}
Test your knowledge with the [DNA Structure Quiz →](quiz.qmd)
:::

Lesson Not Appearing in Navigation

Verify the file path is correct
Re-render the entire site



Styles Not Applying

Ensure css: styles.css is in the YAML front matter
Check that the CSS file is in the correct directory
Clear browser cache and refresh



Images Not Loading

Verify image paths are correct (relative to the QMD file)
Check that images are in the assets/ folder
Ensure image file names match exactly (case-sensitive)



Videos Not Playing

Test video format compatibility (MP4 is most widely supported)
Check video file size (large files may need external hosting)
Verify video codec is web-compatible
